channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: 68 Migrants Are Found Locked Inside Trucks at British Port
item.description: They had been crammed into the vehicles, and several were suffering from chest and abdominal pain, the local ambulance service said.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Survivor Accounts Raise Questions About Yangtze Ship’s Final Moments
item.description: Crew members suggested that there was little time to save the ship or to warn passengers of the impending catastrophe.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: The Oriental Star was lifted on Friday from the Yangtze River in China, four days after it capsized during a heavy storm.

item.title: Chinese Hacking of U.S. Data May Extend to Insurance Companies
item.description: The same attackers who breached the records of millions of government workers appear to be behind similar thefts at Anthem and Premera Blue Cross, cybersecurity experts say.
item.dc:creator: NICOLE PERLROTH, DAVID E. SANGER and JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.media:description: Millions of records for American workers were stolen from the Office of Personnel Management in Washington by hackers.

item.title: Norway Will Divest From Coal in Push Against Climate Change
item.description: Parliament voted to order the nation’s pension fund to shift holdings out of billions of dollars of stock in companies that rely at least 30 percent on coal.
item.dc:creator: JOHN SCHWARTZ

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Scenes from the Tiananmen Memorial Events in Hong Kong
item.description: Twenty-six years after the military suppression of the protests at Tiananmen Square in Beijing, thousands gathered in Hong Kong to mourn those killed.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:credit: Dale De La Rey/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Tens of thousands gathered at the candlelight vigil at Victoria Park, Hong Kong, on Thursday to mark the 26th anniversary of the military crackdown on protests in Tiananmen Square, Beijing.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Pressure from Chinese Authorities Forces Ex-Detained Feminist to Shutter Organization
item.description: Wu Rongrong, the founder of the Weizhiming Women’s Center, said she had to shut down her advocacy group on May 29 after several employees and volunteers left because they and their families had come under police investigation.
item.dc:creator: VANESSA PIAO
item.media:description: Portraits of the five feminists who were detained in March displayed at a protest on their behalf in Hong Kong: Li Tingting and Wei Tingting (top, left to right), and Wang Man, Wu Rongrong and Zheng Churan (bottom, left to right). Ms. Wu said she has shut down her women's rights organization.

item.title: South Korea Identifies Hospital at Center of MERS Virus Outbreak
item.description: The government said it was trying to find everyone who had been there during a two-week period in May in order to contain the further spread of the illness.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Ukraine Repels Separatists in Fierce Fighting, Poroshenko Says
item.description: President Petro O. Poroshenko, speaking at a news conference in the capital, described the battle as a show of strength and resolve by his country’s military.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: The Saturday Profile: North Korean Defector Opens Up About Long-Held Secret: His Homosexuality
item.description: In an autobiographical novel and a recent interview, Jang Yeong-jin described his experiences as a gay man growing up in the totalitarian country.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jang Yeong-jin, 55, is the only known openly gay defector from North Korea living in the South.

item.title: Tsipras and Greece Buy Time From I.M.F.
item.description: Amid tense negotiations, Athens invoked a little-used option to defer June payments to the International Monetary Fund until the end of the month.
item.dc:creator: NIKI KITSANTONIS and LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:description: A cafe in Athens. The economy in Greece has shrunk after five years of austerity measures, and unemployment is high.

item.title: German Stance on Russia Complicates Long-Cultivated Tie as G-7 Meets
item.description: Germany’s role in seeking to isolate President Vladimir V. Putin has left it feeling rankled and mournful about the rupture of a relationship it had nurtured for decades.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Leaders of the Group of 7 powers at a summit meeting in Brussels last year.

item.title: Video of Mexican Prison Riot Highlights a Crisis as Elections Near
item.description: The footage of a deadly melee illustrated the difficulty the government has in controlling inmates in its overcrowded and violent prison system.
item.dc:creator: PAULINA VILLEGAS and RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: High-Speed Rail Aids Disaster Deployments by Chinese Military
item.description: The presence of uniformed personnel on a Shanghai train platform this week highlighted how high-speed rail had facilitated not just family reunions and business deals, but troop movements and disaster relief.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:credit: Didi Kirsten Tatlow/The New York Times
item.media:description: Troops at the Shanghai Hongqiao Railway Station on Tuesday.

item.title: G.O.P.-Led House Votes to Keep Curbs on American Travel to Cuba
item.description: The measure would block new rules issued in January that would significantly ease travel restrictions to Cuba and allow regularly scheduled flights for the first time.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Open Source: French Firm Latest Target of Palestinian-Led Movement to Boycott Israel
item.description: A telecommunications C.E.O. said he would like to cut ties to an Israeli cellphone service provider operating in the West Bank, but activists want more.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Jacques Parizeau, Who Led Second Quebec Separatist Movement, Dies at 84
item.description: Mr. Parizeau wanted Quebec to secede from Canada to help it realize its potential, but after a second failed vote in 1995, he damaged his reputation with a speech explaining why the separatists lost.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN
item.media:description: Jacques Parizeau, then the Parti Québécois leader, acknowledging the crowd at an event in Montreal in October 1992.

item.title: World Briefing: Yemen: Civilians Bombed, Officials Say
item.description: Airstrikes carried out by a military alliance led by Saudi Arabia have killed at least 50 people in the northern Yemeni province of Saada.
item.dc:creator: SHUAIB ALMOSAWA

item.title: World Briefing: Cambodia: Refugee Resettlement Begins
item.description: The choice of impoverished Cambodia as a new home for asylum seekers has so far attracted little interest among the refugees.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Q. And A.: What You Need to Know About MERS
item.description: The outbreak of Middle East respiratory syndrome in South Korea has raised fears about the disease’s potential for further contagion.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.media:description: Tourists Thursday in Myeongdong, a popular shopping area of Seoul. South Korea is experiencing the largest outbreak of MERS to occur outside the Middle East.

item.title: Hacking Linked to China Exposes Millions of U.S. Workers
item.description: The intrusion, which appears to have involved information on about four million current and former government workers, was the third such breach in the last year.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER and JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
